div.p: From France, my dear lord and friend Coignet writes from Paris on October 13th, he has written to me for some time; but I have received nothing. Now, things are going peacefully in France and in many places well with the gospel, and there is great hope. Praise be to God.

Benedict Stocker [Stokar, Stockar] writes from Lyon that he has seen 6000 people in a sermon; when 100 go to mass, 1000 go to the sermon; they are quiet and calm. The king will keep 2000 Swiss mercenaries for his protection; he will let all the others go home. They are being mustered and paid.
November. The priests must sell their goods so that there is money to pay the Swiss mercenaries, and they are present to be paid.

I am very surprised that less than nothing is being reported about the council, about which it is said that they are thinking of returning home soon with a conclusion promulgated and committing the execution to I don't know whom. I wonder if the French delegation, along with the learned men of France, have returned to France after leaving Trent.
To the most excellent man, Mr. Johannes Fabricius, faithful minister of the Church of Chur, my most esteemed and dear lord and brother.
